channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: Sarkozy charged in corruption case
item.description: An investigative judge has charged former French President Nicolas Sarkozy with breach of trust, accusing him of taking advantage of elderly L'Oreal cosmetic heiress Liliane Bettencourt to help fund his 2007 campaign, Sarkozy's attorney, Thierry Herzog, said, according to CNN affiliate BFM-TV.

item.title: Kurd rebel boss calls for Turkey talks
item.description: For decades Abdullah Ocalan called for war against Turkey. Today the jailed founder of the banned Kurdistan Workers' Party is expected to call for reconcilation talks.

item.title: Hacking on S. Korea traced to China
item.description: The suspected cyberattack targeting South Korean banks and broadcasters originated from an IP address in China, South Korean regulators said Thursday, heightening suspicions of North Korean involvement.

item.title: N. Korea: U.S. bases within range
item.description: North Korea's military warns that U.S. bases in Guam and Okinawa are within its "striking range." Pyongyang has also condemned U.S. military exercises in South Korea.

item.title: After 22 years, prisoner walks free
item.description: After nearly 22 years behind bars, David Ranta walked out of a Brooklyn courthouse Thursday afternoon with an apology from a judge and one immediate wish: "Get the hell out of here."

item.title: NY hit-and-run suspect: I'm innocent
item.description: The suspect in a hit-and-run crash that killed a New York couple and their baby told a court Thursday he is innocent of charges of second-degree manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide, the Kings County District Attorney's office said.

item.title: Anglican church head talks gay marriage
item.description: In a week of change at the top for church leaders, the question of same-sex marriage has jumped to the fore.

item.title: Did Colorado shooting end in chase?
item.description: Colorado authorities are working to determine whether a high-speed chase Thursday involving a man who shot repeatedly at law enforcement officers in Texas is related to this week's shooting death of Tom Clements, Colorado's prison chief.

item.title: Police chase ends in crash that kills 7
item.description: Seven suspected undocumented immigrants were killed and eight others injured when a truck being chased by police crashed into a security barrier at a Navy facility in Texas, authorities said Thursday.

item.title: Europe's airline industry on 'knife edge'
item.description: If you're a business traveler in Europe, you'll no doubt have complained at length about the regions' airlines, be it the cost of a plane ticket, the quality of the food or the delays. It's natural to feel hard done-by.

item.title: Australian PM survives ouster attempt
item.description: Julia Gillard survives another attempt to oust her as the prime minister, after no challengers emerged. Her chief rival, Kevin Rudd declined to pit himself against her.

item.title: Police choppers crash at Berlin stadium
item.description: Two police helicopters crashed at Berlin's Olympic Stadium in Germany on Thursday, causing severe injuries, federal police spokesman Meik Gauer said.

item.title: 10 dead, mosques burned in Myanmar
item.description: A dispute between a Muslim gold shop owner and two Buddhist sellers erupted in clashes that left four people dead, at least 20 injured and four mosques burned to the ground in central Myanmar, police said Thursday.

item.title: Scores injured in Canadian crash
item.description: About 100 people suffered minor to moderate injuries in a multi-vehicle crash Thursday south of Edmonton, Canada, Alberta Health Services said on its Twitter feed.

item.title: Car bomb in Pakistan kills 12, injures 32
item.description: A car bomb exploded Thursday at a camp targeting internally displaced people from northwestern Pakistan, killing 12 people and injuring 32 others, police said.

item.title: Bollywood star jailed for Mumbai attacks
item.description: India's top court Thursday sentenced a leading Bollywood star, Sanjay Dutt, to five years in prison in connection with bomb attacks in Mumbai in 1993.

item.title: Paris Jackson quizzed over dad's death
item.description: Paris Jackson, the 14-year-old daughter of Michael Jackson, is being questioned Thursday about her father's last days as part of her family's wrongful death lawsuit against a concert promoter.

item.title: FIFA enlist stars to fight soccer racism
item.description: FIFA are to enlist the help of Kevin-Prince Boateng and other high-profile stars from the world of soccer to help drive racism out of football.

item.title: CNN's Rena Golden passes away at 51
item.description: Many success stories open with humble beginnings. Rena Golden's began in a village near the India-Nepal border.

item.title: Bart Simpson meets Mr. Burns in court
item.description: It was a meeting apparently straight off the TV screen: Bart Simpson called before Mr. Burns after allegedly causing trouble.

item.title: How Obama has weaponized wit
item.description: Barack Obama would make a great stand-up comic, not because he's the funniest president ever but because he uses jokes the same way many of us comedians do: as a weapon.

item.title: Why police raided IMF chief's home?
item.description: IMF Director Christine Lagarde is under investigation in a long-running business dispute. Jim Bittermann reports.

item.title: Girl cruelty plays role in rape culture
item.description: In order to prevent future incidents like the rape of a teenager in Steubenville, Ohio, girls need to be taught to be allies, not rivals, Rachel Simmons says.

item.title: Army chief punished for truth?
item.description: Army Chief of Staff Eric Shinseki lost his job for raising concerns about U.S. preparedness in Iraq, professor says.

item.title: Hans Blix: Iraq War was terrible mistake
item.description: On March 19, 2003, Iraq was invaded by an "alliance of willing states" headed by the U.S. and UK. My U.N. inspection team and I had seen it coming -- and I felt an emptiness when, three days before the invasion, an American official called me to "ask" that we withdraw from the country.

item.title: First results find no chemical weapons used in Syria
item.description: Initial U.S. intelligence suggests Syria did not use chemical weapons in a strike earlier this week, CNN learns, as a suicide bomber claims 42 lives in Damascus.

item.title: Obama eyes 'red line' on Syria
item.description: CNN's Ivan Watson reports on U.S. reaction to possible chemical weapons being used in Syria's civil war.

item.title: Al-assad makes rare appearance
item.description: Syria's President Bashar al-Assad has made a rare "surprise" visit to an educational center in the capital, Damascus, in an apparent effort to show that it is "business as usual" for the regime, despite the country's brutal civil war.

item.title: Explainer: What next for Cyprus?
item.description: Cyprus has become the latest eurozone nation to apply for a bailout amid a financial crisis linked to debt defaults in Greece. The Mediterranean island has a huge banking sector and its public debt is expected to match GDP within the next decade. Proposals to tax existing bank deposits as part of a rescue package have alarmed investors. The Cypriot parliament on March 19 rejected a €10 billion ($13B) eurozone bailout package due to investor alarm over a proposed tax on existing bank deposits as part of the rescue package.

item.title: Why Cyprus has Russians worried
item.description: As CNN's Nick Paton Walsh reports, a Cyprus bailout concerns Russians about higher taxes.

item.title: Obama urges move on peace process
item.description: U.S. President Obama tries to revive the Middle East peace process, urging young Israelis to pressure their leaders to seek peace with Palestinians.

item.title: Obama: 'We cannot give up'
item.description: President Obama and Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas speak with reporters in Ramallah, West Bank.

item.title: Challenge for Obama to deliver
item.description: David Rothkopf says Obama's speech on Israeli-Palestinian process made all parties uncomfortable, like all great speeches. His challenge now is to deliver on the hopes it's raised

item.title: Rockets from Gaza land in Israel
item.description: Two rockets from Gaza slammed into southern Israel on Thursday morning, as U.S. President Barack Obama prepared to leave Jerusalem for Ramallah for meetings with top Palestinian Authority officials.

item.title: The most complicated neighborhood
item.description: The most complicated neighborhood in the world is even more uncertain these days, and what you see ranges from breathtaking to heart-stopping.

item.title: Palestinians want prisoner rights
item.description: Palestinian prisoner rights could be a major roadblock to peace. CNN's Sara Sidner reports.

item.title: Tracking huge great white shark
item.description: Here's a view from aboard a fishing boat of what it's like to nab and tag a great white shark for research purposes.

item.title: Becker: Ronaldo the tennis ace?
item.description: Cristiano Ronaldo has the perfect physique for tennis, according to tennis great Boris Becker.

item.title: 'Miniature TV' in your tummy
item.description: PillCam is a ingestible video camera with a transmitter which lets doctors look inside your digestive tract.

item.title: The man behind 'Lara Croft'
item.description: Ian Livingstone is a legend in the fantasy games world. In 1995, he stumbled upon "Lara Croft" and the rest is history.

item.title: Rodman: Kim Jong Un 'my friend'
item.description: Ato Boldon, Politico's Ben Smith and Reihan Salam discuss criticism over Dennis Rodman's trip to North Korea.

item.title: Marcel Desailly's Ghana regret
item.description: French World Cup winning defender Marcel Desailly tells CNN that he would have loved to play for Ghana at least once.

item.title: 'Batman' helps UK police
item.description: A costumed crusader brought in a man wanted for burglary.

item.title: Go inside a sinkhole
item.description: Ever wonder what a sinkhole looks like on the inside? CNN's David Mattingly dives in for a peek in Florida.

item.title: Can Russia rescue Cypriot banks?
item.description: Cyprus has rejected an EU bailout plan and lobbied Russia to stave off a possible banking collapse. But can Russia help?

item.title: Can Erdogan satisfy PKK demands?
item.description: It was Newrouz, the first day of spring and the Kurdish New Year but was it also the beginning of a new era in Turkey's troubled relation with its Kurdish population?

item.title: Al-assad makes rare public appearance
item.description: Syria's President Bashar al-Assad has made a rare "surprise" visit to an educational center in the capital, Damascus, in an apparent effort to show that it is "business as usual" for the regime, despite the country's brutal civil war.

item.title: Sapphire screens on your next phone?
item.description: The next wave of smartphones and tablets might have super-sturdy screens fashioned from the human-made version of a gemstone.

item.title: Lifting spirits in China through art
item.description: A Chinese art student uses watercolors to paint on trees, hoping to injecting some life into one Chinese city.

item.title: How to find a $2.2 million bowl
item.description: "Antiques Roadshow" appraiser Nicholas Dawes says luck, a sharp eye and an understanding of supply and demand are key for the average yard-saler. But treasures may be closer at hand than you think

item.title: McLaren drivers: We can't compete
item.description: With 182 Formula One wins, McLaren is one of the most successful marques in the history of the sport, but F1's second oldest team could be waiting some time for the next victory.

item.title: Baby resuscitated in supermarket aisle
item.description: A man helps resuscitate a small child in the checkout of an Australian supermarket.

item.title: Australian political assassination misfires
item.description: Prime Minister Julia Gillard has survived another leadership challenge, but the question remains as to why she's such a target and how she's clinging on.

item.title: How leadership vote flopped
item.description: Australian Prime Minister Julia Gillard has survived another attempt to oust her from the job after no challengers emerged to vie for the leadership of the governing party and the country.

item.title: Sisterly love drives grand slam ambition
item.description: They do everything together, and now Poland's tennis sisters Agnieszka and Urszula Radwanska are hoping to take their relationship to a new level by emulating the sport's most famous female siblings.

item.title: Perils of crossing Antarctica in winter
item.description: Listen to Sir Ranulph Fiennes talk about the mission and the frostbite he sustained on his expedition in Antarctica.

item.title: Joss Stone target of murder plot?
item.description: Two men accused of hatching a plot to kill singer Joss Stone were in court today. CNN's Max Foster has more.

item.title: Fighting cyber crime tests skills
item.description: "UK cyber security champion" Stephen Miller says black market-funded cyber attacks are threatening our freedom.

item.title: Burned Iraqi boy standing tall
item.description: In 2007, men poured gas on Youssif's face and set him on fire outside his Baghdad home -- but the Iraqi boy survived and is now thriving in the U.S.

item.title: Malawi 'widow sex' tradition must end
item.description: Seodi White is a lawyer fighting to stop 'Widow Cleansing' a tradition in which a widow is expected to have sex, "to cleanse her of her husband's spirit."

item.title: Rena Golden: News leader
item.description: Many success stories open with humble beginnings. Rena Golden's began in a village near the India-Nepal border.

item.title: Does sexy sell flights?
item.description: Many Asian airlines base their brand image on young, attractive flight attendants

item.title: Writer who scared readers silly
item.description: Nearly four decades after he brought an invasion of mutant, flesh-eating rodents to London with his first novel, "The Rats," UK chiller writer James Herbert has died aged 69.

item.title: From I.T. guy to top Syrian rebel
item.description: Why Ghassan Hitto gave up a safe job as an information technology manager in Texas to lead rebels in Syria.

item.title: Miniskirt ban in Korea?
item.description: Netizens and pop stars worry about censorship and hemlines. But are they getting their knickers in a knot for no reason?

item.title: Ramallah residents angry at Obama
item.description: The most complicated neighborhood in the world is even more uncertain these days, and what you see ranges from breathtaking to heart-stopping.

item.title: City with worst light pollution is...
item.description: If you seek the majestic sweep of star-studded skies, Hong Kong is not your spot. Its night sky is 1,000 times brighter than international norms.

item.title: Gay people 'live in 50 Americas'
item.description: Three years ago, when Scott Hamilton moved from New York to Oklahoma for work, his marriage, and all the rights that went with it, dissolved in the transition.

item.title: Guantanamo device baffles lawyers
item.description: A photo of a listening device in a room where attorneys met with terror detainees at Guantanamo Bay caused a stir this month, but a senior military official says it is a relic from the days when interrogations occurred in the facility.

item.title: Most expensive 'billionaire' cities
item.description: Hong Kong's billionaire properties are the most expensive in the world, according to global real estate firm, Savills.

item.title: Bye, chairs. Hello, walking meetings
item.description: Steve Tobak, a California-based management consultant, recalls the agonizing one-on-one meetings he sat through years ago with a micromanaging boss. But when one day the boss changed tack and asked him to go on walks instead, it transformed their working and personal relationship.

item.title: Bigger payday for U.S. Open prize
item.description: He's enjoyed unprecedented success off the court, now Roger Federer has helped pave the way for some major changes at the U.S Open.

item.title: Rainbow house gets revenge
item.description: A house is painted in rainbow colors to counteract anti-gay neighbors. CNN's Jeanne Moos reports.

item.title: Why Arab world must talk about sex
item.description: Fear that greater personal and sexual freedom will lead to a free-for-all and a violation of Islamic principles is holding Egypt back from democracy, writes Shereen El Feki.

item.title: China's workforce at a crossroads
item.description: China's unprecedented climb to the world's second largest economy was built on the back of its migrant workers. CNN's "On China" examines how workers, empowered by technology, are demanding more rights.

item.title: Robots probe sea's hidden depths
item.description: Despite most humans' land-centric view, Earth is an ocean planet. The global ocean covers more than two-thirds of our planet's surface and makes life as we know it possible: it produces half of the oxygen we breathe, helps regulate our climate and provides the single largest habitat for life on Earth.

item.title: Can extinct species be brought back?
item.description: CNN's Lisa Sylvester looks at how science is very close to being able to give new life to extinct animals.

item.title: Activist: Pope backs civil unions?
item.description: While still an archbishop, an activist says Pope Francis expressed private support for civil unions, but said that Argentina "wasn't ready for" same-sex marriage.

item.title: Twitter: Seven years, seven lives
item.description: Twitter turns 7 on Wednesday, and in some ways, it's like a lot of 7-year-olds.

item.title: 'Africa's tallest building' planned
item.description: A $10 billion high-tech hub in Ghana could become home to Africa's tallest building, and bring global IT firms to the country.

item.title: Ship becomes giant art canvas
item.description: Welcome to the Duke of Lancaster. A hulking, rusting, abandoned ship on the Dee Estuary in north Wales, which has become a canvas for some of the most renowned graffiti artists from across Europe.

item.title: The 'girl with dancing horse'
item.description: Charlotte Dujardin became known as "The girl with the dancing horse" at the London Olympics, where she completed an incredible journey from low-paid stable girl to becoming the new star of dressage.

item.title: Cannabis 'scratch n' sniff' cards
item.description: Crimestoppers explain to CNN how scratch n' sniff cannabis cards help to identify illegal cannabis growers in London.

item.title: The city hiding stars
item.description: If you want a place to see the majestic sweep of the Milky Way -- or even any star at night -- then put Hong Kong at the bottom of your must-visit list.

item.title: HK residents: Turn off the lights
item.description: Study finds Hong Kong is the most light polluted city on Earth. CNN's Andrew Stevens reports.

item.title: Can Obama deliver on peace push?
item.description: Opinion: U.S. President Obama's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian relationship made all parties uncomfortable. But David Rothkopf argues that he must stay active to fulfill hopes.

item.title: 'Baby' photo of universe
item.description: The picture of our early universe just got sharper, and tells scientists with greater precision many important facts about how the universe evolved.

item.title: Obama's peace push
item.description: President Obama and Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas speak with reporters in Ramallah, West Bank.

item.title: Gaza fighters
item.description: As U.S. President Obama urges peace between Israelis and Palestinians, CNN's Sara Sidner meets a new generation of Gaza fighters.

item.title: Cyprus: What next?
item.description: Cyprus has become the latest eurozone nation to apply for a bailout amid a financial crisis linked to debt defaults in Greece. The Mediterranean island has a huge banking sector and its public debt is expected to match GDP within the next decade. Proposals to tax existing bank deposits as part of a rescue package have alarmed investors. The Cypriot parliament on March 19 rejected a €10 billion ($13B) eurozone bailout package due to investor alarm over a proposed tax on existing bank deposits as part of the rescue package.

item.title: 'Widow sex'
item.description: Seodi White is a lawyer fighting to stop 'Widow Cleansing' a tradition in which a widow is expected to have sex, "to cleanse her of her husband's spirit."

item.title: Korean miniskirt ban
item.description: Netizens and pop stars worry about censorship and hemlines. But are they getting their knickers in a knot for no reason?

item.title: Pope and civil union
item.description: Less than an hour after he fired off an angry letter to Catholic Church leaders about their handling of Argentina's same-sex marriage debate, Marcelo Marquez says his phone rang.

item.title: Robots probe ocean depths
item.description: Despite most humans' land-centric view, Earth is an ocean planet. The global ocean covers more than two-thirds of our planet's surface and makes life as we know it possible: it produces half of the oxygen we breathe, helps regulate our climate and provides the single largest habitat for life on Earth.

item.title: Hong Kong: Ivory's Fort Knox
item.description: Hong Kong is fast becoming the Fort Knox of ivory.

item.title: Global warming increases pollen
item.description: With global warming, temperature extremes are becoming a norm -- and that's bad news for allergy sufferers.

item.title: World rejects polar bear plan
item.description: A U.S. plan to give new protection to polar bears was voted down Thursday at an international conference on endangered species.

item.title: Study warns global warming 'epic'
item.description: Global warming has propelled Earth's climate from one of its coldest decades since the last ice age to one of its hottest -- in just one century.

item.title: Philippines taps into geothermal
item.description: Eco Solutions looks at how the Philippines is tapping into its geothermal potential.

item.title: Macau's motorcycles go electric
item.description: A Macau company's love for motorcycles is helping the planet at the same time. CNN's Andrew Stevens reports.

item.title: Environmentalists fill U.S. National Mall
item.description: Marching, dancing and poster-waving environmentalists chanting "Hey, Obama. We don't want no climate drama," packed several blocks on and around Washington's National Mall on Sunday, hoping to spur President Barack Obama to take strong measures against climate change.

item.title: China's workforce at a crossroads
item.description: China's extraordinary climb to the world's second largest economy was built on the back of Chinese workers, many of whom left rural farms to migrate for work in coastal factories.

item.title: Chinese bowl sells for $2.2 million
item.description: A rare Chinese bowl bought for about $3 from a yard sale in the U.S. sold for $2.2 million at an auction in New York on Tuesday.

item.title: Pollution 'an economic concern'
item.description: CNN's Philippe Cousteau speaks about Chinese pollution and what can be done to clean up the environmental problems.

item.title: Hollywood dream lost in translation
item.description: When China's most successful homegrown movie went on international release last month, hopes were high that the slapstick comedy, which has drawn comparisons with "The Hangover," would blaze a trail for Chinese-language cinema.

item.title: Xi: China's new boss in a hurry
item.description: Xi Jinping has taken the center stage as China's undisputed paramount leader.

item.title: Li Keqiang named Chinese premier
item.description: Li Keqiang on Friday was named China's premier, the No. 2 position in the Chinese government, completing the once-a-decade transition of leadership in the world's most populous nation.

item.title: Chinese farm claims dead pigs
item.description: A Chinese farm admitted to dumping dead pigs into Huangpu River, which had about 6,000 bloated carcasses pulled from its water this week, state media reported.

item.title: Will China finally 'bite' North Korea?
item.description: North Korea, China's longtime ally, has vexed Beijing for years with its rocket launches, nuclear tests, kidnapping of Chinese fishermen and other erratic behavior. Yet, Beijing has run interference at the United Nations to temper punishments against Pyongyang, and has even helped Pyongyang circumvent sanctions.

item.title: Coca-Cola probed over mapping
item.description: The government of a remote province in western China says it is investigating Coca-Cola over allegations that it illegally mapped parts of the province, as China and the US engage in an escalating war of words over cyber espionage.

item.title: Inflation warning from central bank
item.description: China must be "on high alert" against inflation, central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan said on Wednesday, striking a hawkish tone at his most important news conference of the year.
